name: Chlorpromazine + Promethazine
summary: A combination of a first-generation antipsychotic (chlorpromazine) and an antihistamine (promethazine), historically used for sedation, agitation, and nausea.
description: This combination pairs chlorpromazine, a phenothiazine antipsychotic with sedative properties, and promethazine, a phenothiazine derivative with strong antihistaminic and antiemetic effects. Historically, it has been used in psychiatry for rapid tranquilization in acute agitation, as well as in medical settings for severe nausea, vomiting, and perioperative sedation. Due to safety concerns and the availability of safer alternatives, its psychiatric use has largely declined.

contraindications: Children under 2 years (promethazine risk of respiratory depression)

items: Management of severe nausea and vomiting

sections.text: Chlorpromazine blocks dopamine D2 receptors, producing antipsychotic and sedative effects. Promethazine blocks histamine H1 receptors and has anticholinergic and antidopaminergic properties, contributing to sedation and antiemetic action.

adult.agitation: Chlorpromazine 25–50 mg + promethazine 25–50 mg IM as needed
adult.nausea: Chlorpromazine 10–25 mg + promethazine 12.5–25 mg orally or IM every 4–6 hours as needed

sections.geriatric: Use lowest effective doses; monitor closely for sedation and hypotension
sections.hepatic_impairment: Use with caution; dose adjustments may be required
sections.renal_impairment: No adjustment generally needed, but monitor

sections.text: IM onset within 20–60 minutes; oral onset 30–60 minutes; duration 4–8 hours.

sections.black_box: Elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis treated with antipsychotic drugs are at increased risk of death.
other: Promethazine contraindicated in children <2 years due to fatal respiratory depression risk
Caution in patients with seizure disorders
Increased sedation and fall risk in elderly

items: Signs of respiratory depression (especially in pediatrics)

sections.pregnancy: Category C; use if benefits outweigh risks
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; may cause sedation in infant
sections.pediatrics: Promethazine contraindicated in <2 years; use lowest effective dose in older children
sections.geriatrics: Increased sensitivity to sedation and hypotension; start low and go slow

sections.text: Not typically needed for short-term or single-dose use; if given regularly, taper antipsychotic gradually.

items: Combination sometimes compounded in hospitals for acute psychiatric emergencies
Supplanted by benzodiazepines or atypical antipsychotics for rapid tranquilization
Still occasionally used in resource-limited settings
